mn89:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati medāḷupaṃ nāma sakyānaṃ nigamo.
mn89:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near the Sakyan town named Medaḷumpa.
mn89:1.2.comm: This town, the spelling of which is uncertain, is not mentioned elsewhere.

mn89:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājā pasenadi kosalo nagarakaṃ anuppatto hoti kenacideva karaṇīyena.
mn89:2.1.eng: Now at that time King Pasenadi of Kosala had arrived at Townsville on some business.
mn89:2.1.comm: “Townsville” is a literal rendering of nagaraka. I translate it in homage to the town in northern Queensland where a chance encounter with a joey set me on the path to the Dhamma.

mn89:2.2.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo dīghaṃ kārāyanaṃ āmantesi:

mn89:2.3.pli: “yojehi, samma kārāyana, bhadrāni bhadrāni yānāni, uyyānabhūmiṃ gacchāma subhūmiṃ dassanāyā”ti.
mn89:2.3.eng: “My good Kārāyana, harness the finest chariots. We will go to a park and see the scenery.”

mn89:2.4.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho dīgho kārāyano rañño pasenadissa kosalassa paṭissutvā bhadrāni bhadrāni yānāni yojāpetvā rañño pasenadissa kosalassa paṭivedesi:
mn89:2.4.eng: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied Dīgha Kārāyana. He harnessed the chariots and informed the king,

mn89:2.5.pli: “yuttāni kho te, deva, bhadrāni bhadrāni yānāni.

mn89:3.1.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhadraṃ yānaṃ abhiruhitvā bhadrehi bhadrehi yānehi nagarakamhā niyyāsi mahaccā rājānubhāvena.
mn89:3.1.eng: Then King Pasenadi mounted a fine carriage and, along with other fine carriages, set out in full royal pomp from Townsville,

mn89:3.2.comm: The word ārāma, from a root meaning “to enjoy”, originally referred to a cultivated and pleasant parkland enjoyed for recreation. Such places were favorite dwelling places for ascetics, and became the sites for developed monasteries. In this sutta we see both senses. Here Pasenadi enjoys an ārāma (“park”) for recreation. Below we see the Buddha staying in an ārāma with a community of mendicants, featuring substantial private dwellings (vihāra) with lockable doors; in other words, a “monastery” (MN 89:8.1).

mn89:3.3.pli: Yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi, yānena gantvā yānā paccorohitvā pattikova ārāmaṃ pāvisi.
mn89:3.3.eng: He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and entered the park on foot.

mn89:4.1.pli: Addasā kho rājā pasenadi kosalo ārāme jaṅghāvihāraṃ anucaṅkamamāno anuvicaramāno rukkhamūlāni pāsādikāni pasādanīyāni appasaddāni appanigghosāni vijanavātāni manussarāhasseyyakāni paṭisallānasāruppāni.
mn89:4.1.eng: As he was going for a walk in the park he saw roots of trees that were impressive and inspiring, quiet and still, far from the madding crowd, remote from human settlements, and fit for retreat.

mn89:4.2.eng: The sight reminded him right away of the Buddha:

mn89:4.3.pli: “imāni kho tāni rukkhamūlāni pāsādikāni pasādanīyāni appasaddāni appanigghosāni vijanavātāni manussarāhasseyyakāni paṭisallānasāruppāni, yattha sudaṃ mayaṃ taṃ bhagavantaṃ payirupāsāma arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhan”ti.
mn89:4.3.eng: “These roots of trees, so impressive and inspiring, are like those where we used to pay homage to the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.”
mn89:4.3.comm: Evidently the Buddha used to meditate on emptiness in these very woods (MN 121:3.1).

mn89:4.4.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo dīghaṃ kārāyanaṃ āmantesi:

mn89:4.5.pli: “imāni kho, samma kārāyana, tāni rukkhamūlāni pāsādikāni pasādanīyāni appasaddāni appanigghosāni vijanavātāni manussarāhasseyyakāni paṭisallānasāruppāni, yattha sudaṃ mayaṃ taṃ bhagavantaṃ payirupāsāma arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ.
mn89:4.5.eng: “These roots of trees, so impressive and inspiring, are like those where we used to pay homage to the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

mn89:4.6.pli: Kahaṃ nu kho, samma kārāyana, etarahi so bhagavā viharati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho”ti?
mn89:4.6.eng: My good Kārāyana, where is that Buddha at present?”

mn89:5.1.eng: “Great king, there is a Sakyan town named Medaḷumpa.

mn89:5.2.pli: Tattha so bhagavā etarahi viharati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho”ti.
mn89:5.2.eng: That’s where the Buddha is now staying.”

mn89:5.3.pli: “Kīvadūre pana, samma kārāyana, nagarakamhā medāḷupaṃ nāma sakyānaṃ nigamo hotī”ti?
mn89:5.3.eng: “But how far away is that town?”

mn89:5.6.eng: We can get there while it’s still light.”

mn89:5.7.pli: “Tena hi, samma kārāyana, yojehi bhadrāni bhadrāni yānāni, gamissāma mayaṃ taṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhan”ti.
mn89:5.7.eng: “Well then, harness the chariots, and we shall go to see the Buddha.”

mn89:5.8.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho dīgho kārāyano rañño pasenadissa kosalassa paṭissutvā bhadrāni bhadrāni yānāni yojāpetvā rañño pasenadissa kosalassa paṭivedesi:
mn89:5.8.eng: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied Dīgha Kārāyana. He harnessed the chariots and informed the king,

mn89:5.9.pli: “yuttāni kho te, deva, bhadrāni bhadrāni yānāni.

mn89:6.1.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhadraṃ yānaṃ abhiruhitvā bhadrehi bhadrehi yānehi nagarakamhā yena medāḷupaṃ nāma sakyānaṃ nigamo tena pāyāsi.
mn89:6.1.eng: Then King Pasenadi mounted a fine carriage and, along with other fine carriages, set out from Townsville to Medaḷumpa.

mn89:6.2.pli: Teneva divasāvasesena medāḷupaṃ nāma sakyānaṃ nigamaṃ sampāpuṇi.
mn89:6.2.eng: He reached the town while it was still light

mn89:6.3.eng: and headed for the monastery grounds.

mn89:6.4.pli: Yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi, yānena gantvā yānā paccorohitvā pattikova ārāmaṃ pāvisi.
mn89:6.4.eng: He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and entered the monastery on foot.

mn89:7.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā bhikkhū abbhokāse caṅkamanti.
mn89:7.1.eng: At that time several mendicants were walking mindfully in the open air.

mn89:7.2.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te bhikkhū etadavoca:
mn89:7.2.eng: King Pasenadi of Kosala went up to them and said,

mn89:7.3.pli: “kahaṃ nu kho, bhante, etarahi so bhagavā viharati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho?
mn89:7.3.eng: “Sirs, where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?

mn89:7.4.pli: Dassanakāmā hi mayaṃ taṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhan”ti.
mn89:7.4.eng: For I want to see him.”

mn89:8.1.pli: “Eso, mahārāja, vihāro saṃvutadvāro. Tena appasaddo upasaṅkamitvā ataramāno āḷindaṃ pavisitvā ukkāsitvā aggaḷaṃ ākoṭehi. Vivarissati bhagavā te dvāran”ti.
mn89:8.1.eng: “Great king, that’s his dwelling, with the door closed. Approach it quietly, without hurrying; go onto the porch, clear your throat, and knock on the door-panel. The Buddha will open the door.”

mn89:8.2.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo tattheva khaggañca uṇhīsañca dīghassa kārāyanassa pādāsi.
mn89:8.2.eng: The king right away presented his sword and turban to Dīgha Kārāyana,

mn89:8.4.pli: “rahāyati kho dāni rājā, idheva dāni mayā ṭhātabban”ti.
mn89:8.4.eng: “Now the king seeks privacy. I should wait here.”
mn89:8.4.comm: Kārāyana’s response gives no hint of anything other than loyal service.

mn89:8.5.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo yena so vihāro saṃvutadvāro tena appasaddo upasaṅkamitvā ataramāno āḷindaṃ pavisitvā ukkāsitvā aggaḷaṃ ākoṭesi. Vivari bhagavā dvāraṃ.
mn89:8.5.eng: Then the king approached the Buddha’s dwelling, cleared his throat and knocked on the door-panel, and the Buddha opened the door.

mn89:9.1.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo vihāraṃ pavisitvā bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavato pādāni mukhena ca paricumbati, pāṇīhi ca parisambāhati, nāmañca sāveti:
mn89:9.1.eng: King Pasenadi entered the dwelling, and bowed with his head at the Buddha’s feet, caressing them and covering them with kisses, and pronounced his name:
mn89:9.1.comm: For similar gestures, see Koṇḍañña at SN 8.9:1.2, the brahmin Mānatthaddha (“Stuck-up”) at SN 7.15:3.2, the brahmin Brahmāyu at MN 91:34.1, and Pasenadi again at AN 10.30:2.2.

mn89:9.2.eng: “Sir, I am Pasenadi, king of Kosala!

mn89:9.3.eng: I am Pasenadi, king of Kosala!”

mn89:9.4.pli: “Kiṃ pana tvaṃ, mahārāja, atthavasaṃ sampassamāno imasmiṃ sarīre evarūpaṃ paramanipaccakāraṃ karosi, mittūpahāraṃ upadaṃsesī”ti?
mn89:9.4.eng: “But great king, for what reason do you demonstrate such utmost devotion for this body, conveying your manifest love?”

mn89:10.1.pli: “Atthi kho me, bhante, bhagavati dhammanvayo hoti:
mn89:10.1.eng: “Sir, I infer about the Buddha from the teaching:
mn89:10.1.comm: See SN 12.33 and notes for discussion.

mn89:10.2.pli: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.
mn89:10.2.eng: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’
mn89:10.2.comm: This is an abbreviated form of the full devotions to the Triple Gem.

mn89:10.3.pli: Idhāhaṃ, bhante, passāmi eke samaṇabrāhmaṇe pariyantakataṃ brahmacariyaṃ carante dasapi vassāni, vīsampi vassāni, tiṃsampi vassāni, cattārīsampi vassāni.
mn89:10.3.eng: It happens, sir, that I see some ascetics and brahmins leading the spiritual life only for a limited period: ten, twenty, thirty, or forty years.

mn89:10.4.pli: Te aparena samayena sunhātā suvilittā kappitakesamassū pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitā samaṅgībhūtā paricārenti.
mn89:10.4.eng: Some time later—nicely bathed and anointed, with hair and beard dressed—they amuse themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
mn89:10.4.comm: He knows this because they worked for him as spies (SN 3.11:7.3, Ud 6.2:8.3).

mn89:10.5.pli: Idha panāhaṃ, bhante, bhikkhū passāmi yāvajīvaṃ āpāṇakoṭikaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carante.
mn89:10.5.eng: But here I see the mendicants leading the spiritual life entirely full and pure as long as they live, to their last breath.
mn89:10.5.comm: While Buddhist mendicants may disrobe at any time, their intention is to practice for life.

mn89:10.6.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ, bhante, ito bahiddhā aññaṃ evaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ samanupassāmi.
mn89:10.6.eng: I don’t see any other spiritual life elsewhere so full and pure.

mn89:10.7.pli: Ayampi kho me, bhante, bhagavati dhammanvayo hoti:
mn89:10.7.eng: That’s why I infer this about the Buddha from the teaching:

mn89:10.8.pli: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.
mn89:10.8.eng: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’

mn89:11.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhante, rājānopi rājūhi vivadanti, khattiyāpi khattiyehi vivadanti, brāhmaṇāpi brāhmaṇehi vivadanti, gahapatayopi gahapatīhi vivadanti, mātāpi puttena vivadati, puttopi mātarā vivadati, pitāpi puttena vivadati, puttopi pitarā vivadati, bhātāpi bhaginiyā vivadati, bhaginīpi bhātarā vivadati, sahāyopi sahāyena vivadati.
mn89:11.1.eng: Furthermore, kings fight with kings, aristocrats fight with aristocrats, brahmins fight with brahmins, householders fight with householders. A mother fights with her child, child with mother, father with child, and child with father. Brother fights with brother, brother with sister, sister with brother, and friend fights with friend.
mn89:11.1.comm: PTS text includes brother with brother.

mn89:11.2.pli: Idha panāhaṃ, bhante, bhikkhū passāmi samagge sammodamāne avivadamāne khīrodakībhūte aññamaññaṃ piyacakkhūhi sampassante viharante.
mn89:11.2.eng: But here I see the mendicants living in harmony, appreciating each other, without dispute, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes.

mn89:11.3.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ, bhante, ito bahiddhā aññaṃ evaṃ samaggaṃ parisaṃ samanupassāmi.
mn89:11.3.eng: I don’t see any other assembly elsewhere so harmonious.

mn89:11.4.pli: Ayampi kho me, bhante, bhagavati dhammanvayo hoti:
mn89:11.4.eng: So I infer this about the Buddha from the teaching:

mn89:11.5.pli: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.
mn89:11.5.eng: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’

mn89:12.1.pli: Puna caparāhaṃ, bhante, ārāmena ārāmaṃ, uyyānena uyyānaṃ anucaṅkamāmi anuvicarāmi.
mn89:12.1.eng: Furthermore, I have walked and wandered from monastery to monastery and from park to park.

mn89:12.2.pli: Sohaṃ tattha passāmi eke samaṇabrāhmaṇe kise lūkhe dubbaṇṇe uppaṇḍuppaṇḍukajāte dhamanisanthatagatte, na viya maññe cakkhuṃ bandhante janassa dassanāya.
mn89:12.2.eng: There I’ve seen some ascetics and brahmins who are thin, haggard, pale, and veiny—hardly a captivating sight for people, you’d think.
mn89:12.2.comm: This is a standard description of monastics who are unhappy and dissatisfied for whatever reason, eg. Bu Ss 1:1.1.3.

mn89:12.4.pli: ‘addhā ime āyasmanto anabhiratā vā brahmacariyaṃ caranti, atthi vā tesaṃ kiñci pāpaṃ kammaṃ kataṃ paṭicchannaṃ;
mn89:12.4.eng: ‘Clearly these venerables lead the spiritual life dissatisfied, or they’re hiding some bad deed they’ve done.

mn89:12.5.pli: tathā hi ime āyasmanto kisā lūkhā dubbaṇṇā uppaṇḍuppaṇḍukajātā dhamanisanthatagattā, na viya maññe cakkhuṃ bandhanti janassa dassanāyā’ti.
mn89:12.5.eng: That’s why they’re thin, haggard, pale, and veiny—hardly a captivating sight for people, you’d think.’

mn89:12.6.eng: I went up to them and said:

mn89:12.7.pli: ‘kiṃ nu kho tumhe āyasmanto kisā lūkhā dubbaṇṇā uppaṇḍuppaṇḍukajātā dhamanisanthatagattā, na viya maññe cakkhuṃ bandhatha janassa dassanāyā’ti?
mn89:12.7.eng: ‘Venerables, why are you so thin, haggard, pale, and veiny—hardly a captivating sight for people, you’d think?’

mn89:12.9.comm: The commentary glosses kularogo (“family sickness”), showing it must accept the reading bandhu (“relative”). However, the parallel at MA 213 has 白病, which supports the variant paṇḍukarogino (“jaundice”).

mn89:12.10.pli: Idha panāhaṃ, bhante, bhikkhū passāmi haṭṭhapahaṭṭhe udaggudagge abhiratarūpe pīṇindriye appossukke pannalome paradattavutte migabhūtena cetasā viharante.
mn89:12.10.eng: But here I see mendicants always smiling and joyful, obviously happy, with cheerful faces, living relaxed, unruffled, surviving on charity, their hearts free as a wild deer.

mn89:12.12.pli: ‘addhā ime āyasmanto tassa bhagavato sāsane uḷāraṃ pubbenāparaṃ visesaṃ jānanti;
mn89:12.12.eng: ‘Clearly these venerables have realized a higher distinction in the Buddha’s instructions than they had before.

mn89:12.13.pli: tathā hi ime āyasmanto haṭṭhapahaṭṭhā udaggudaggā abhiratarūpā pīṇindriyā appossukkā pannalomā paradattavuttā migabhūtena cetasā viharantī’ti.
mn89:12.13.eng: That’s why these venerables are always smiling and joyful, obviously happy, with cheerful faces, living relaxed, unruffled, surviving on charity, their hearts free as a wild deer.’

mn89:12.14.pli: Ayampi kho me, bhante, bhagavati dhammanvayo hoti:
mn89:12.14.eng: So I infer this about the Buddha from the teaching:

mn89:12.15.pli: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.
mn89:12.15.eng: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’

mn89:13.1.pli: Puna caparāhaṃ, bhante, rājā khattiyo muddhāvasitto;
mn89:13.1.eng: Furthermore, as an anointed aristocratic king

mn89:13.2.pli: pahomi ghātetāyaṃ vā ghātetuṃ, jāpetāyaṃ vā jāpetuṃ, pabbājetāyaṃ vā pabbājetuṃ.
mn89:13.2.eng: I am able to execute, fine, or banish those who are guilty.

mn89:13.3.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, aḍḍakaraṇe nisinnassa antarantarā kathaṃ opātenti.
mn89:13.3.eng: Yet when I’m sitting in court they interrupt me.
mn89:13.3.comm: Read aḍḍa (variants attha, aṭṭa) which in Sanskrit has the senses “solve, infer, argue, discern”. The commentary interprets aḍḍakaraṇa as the “place of judgement” i.e. the court, which is clearly the case at DN 17:1.11.1.

mn89:13.5.pli: ‘mā me bhonto aḍḍakaraṇe nisinnassa antarantarā kathaṃ opātetha, kathāpariyosānaṃ me bhonto āgamentū’ti.
mn89:13.5.eng: to stop interrupting me and wait until I’ve finished speaking.
mn89:13.5.comm: Pasenadi speaks of his frustrations in judging at SN 3.7. He was getting old and passing his duties to his son.

mn89:13.6.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, antarantarā kathaṃ opātenti.

mn89:13.7.eng: But here I’ve seen the mendicants

mn89:13.8.pli: yasmiṃ samaye bhagavā anekasatāya parisāya dhammaṃ deseti, neva tasmiṃ samaye bhagavato sāvakānaṃ khipitasaddo vā hoti ukkāsitasaddo vā.
mn89:13.8.eng: while the Buddha is teaching an assembly of many hundreds, and there is no sound of his disciples coughing or clearing their throats.

mn89:13.9.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhante, bhagavā anekasatāya parisāya dhammaṃ deseti.
mn89:13.9.eng: Once it so happened that the Buddha was teaching an assembly of many hundreds.

mn89:13.10.eng: Then one of his disciples cleared their throat.

mn89:13.11.eng: And one of their spiritual companions nudged them with their knee, to indicate:

mn89:13.12.pli: ‘appasaddo āyasmā hotu, māyasmā saddamakāsi; satthā no bhagavā dhammaṃ desetī’ti.
mn89:13.12.eng: ‘Hush, venerable, don’t make a sound! Our teacher, the Blessed One, is teaching!’

mn89:13.15.pli: Adaṇḍena vata kira, bho, asatthena evaṃ suvinītā parisā bhavissatī’ti.
mn89:13.15.eng: how an assembly can be so well trained without rod or sword!’
mn89:13.15.comm: The future tense bhavissati here expresses surprise or wonder, for which compare AN 4.36:1.6.

mn89:13.16.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ, bhante, ito bahiddhā aññaṃ evaṃ suvinītaṃ parisaṃ samanupassāmi.
mn89:13.16.eng: I don’t see any other assembly elsewhere so well trained.
mn89:13.16.comm: For the poor behavior of other ascetics, see MN 77:6.21.

mn89:13.17.pli: Ayampi kho me, bhante, bhagavati dhammanvayo hoti:
mn89:13.17.eng: So I infer this about the Buddha from the teaching:

mn89:13.18.pli: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.
mn89:13.18.eng: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’

mn89:14.1.pli: Puna caparāhaṃ, bhante, passāmi idhekacce khattiyapaṇḍite nipuṇe kataparappavāde vālavedhirūpe. Te bhindantā maññe caranti paññāgatena diṭṭhigatāni.
mn89:14.1.eng: Furthermore, I’ve seen some clever aristocrats who are subtle, accomplished in the doctrines of others, hair-splitters. You’d think they live to demolish convictions with their intellect.
mn89:14.1.comm: This passage on conversion of disputants is also found at MN 27:4.2.

mn89:14.3.pli: ‘samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo amukaṃ nāma gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā osarissatī’ti.
mn89:14.3.eng: ‘So, gentlemen, that ascetic Gotama will come down to such and such village or town.’

mn89:14.5.pli: ‘imaṃ mayaṃ pañhaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ upasaṅkamitvā pucchissāma.
mn89:14.5.eng: ‘We’ll approach the ascetic Gotama and ask him this question.

mn89:14.6.pli: Evañce no puṭṭho evaṃ byākarissati, evamassa mayaṃ vādaṃ āropessāma;
mn89:14.6.eng: If he answers like this, we’ll refute him like that;

mn89:14.7.pli: evañcepi no puṭṭho evaṃ byākarissati, evampissa mayaṃ vādaṃ āropessāmā’ti.
mn89:14.7.eng: and if he answers like that, we’ll refute him like this.’

mn89:14.9.pli: ‘samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo amukaṃ nāma gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā osaṭo’ti.

mn89:14.11.pli: Te bhagavā dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti.
mn89:14.11.eng: The Buddha educates, encourages, fires up, and inspires them with a Dhamma talk.

mn89:14.12.pli: Te bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya sandassitā samādapitā samuttejitā sampahaṃsitā na ceva bhagavantaṃ pañhaṃ pucchanti, kuto vādaṃ āropessanti?
mn89:14.12.eng: They don’t even get around to asking their question to the Buddha, so how could they refute his answer?

mn89:14.14.pli: Ayampi kho me, bhante, bhagavati dhammanvayo hoti:
mn89:14.14.eng: So I infer this about the Buddha from the teaching:

mn89:14.15.pli: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.
mn89:14.15.eng: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’

mn89:15.1.pli: Puna caparāhaṃ, bhante, passāmi idhekacce brāhmaṇapaṇḍite …pe…
mn89:15.1.eng: Furthermore, I see some clever brahmins …

mn89:17.1.pli: samaṇapaṇḍite nipuṇe kataparappavāde vālavedhirūpe. Te bhindantā maññe caranti paññāgatena diṭṭhigatāni.
mn89:17.1.eng: some clever ascetics who are subtle, accomplished in the doctrines of others, hair-splitters. …

mn89:17.3.pli: ‘samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo amukaṃ nāma gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā osarissatī’ti.

mn89:17.5.pli: ‘imaṃ mayaṃ pañhaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ upasaṅkamitvā pucchissāma.

mn89:17.6.pli: Evañce no puṭṭho evaṃ byākarissati, evamassa mayaṃ vādaṃ āropessāma;

mn89:17.7.pli: evañcepi no puṭṭho evaṃ byākarissati, evampissa mayaṃ vādaṃ āropessāmā’ti.

mn89:17.9.pli: ‘samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo amukaṃ nāma gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā osaṭo’ti.

mn89:17.11.pli: Te bhagavā dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti.

mn89:17.12.pli: Te bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya sandassitā samādapitā samuttejitā sampahaṃsitā na ceva bhagavantaṃ pañhaṃ pucchanti, kuto vādaṃ āropessanti?
mn89:17.12.eng: They don’t even get around to asking their question to the Buddha, so how could they refute his answer?

mn89:17.13.pli: Aññadatthu bhagavantaṃyeva okāsaṃ yācanti agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāya.
mn89:17.13.eng: Invariably, they ask the ascetic Gotama for the chance to go forth.

mn89:17.14.eng: And he gives them the going-forth.

mn89:17.15.pli: Te tathāpabbajitā samānā ekā vūpakaṭṭhā appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharantā nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.
mn89:17.15.eng: Soon after going forth, living withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, they realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. They live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

mn89:17.17.pli: ‘manaṃ vata, bho, anassāma; manaṃ vata, bho, panassāma’.
mn89:17.17.eng: ‘We were almost lost! We almost perished!

mn89:17.18.pli: Mayañhi pubbe assamaṇāva samānā samaṇāmhāti paṭijānimhā, abrāhmaṇāva samānā brāhmaṇāmhāti paṭijānimhā, anarahantova samānā arahantāmhāti paṭijānimhā.
mn89:17.18.eng: For we used to claim that we were ascetics, brahmins, and perfected ones, but we were none of these things.

mn89:17.19.pli: ‘Idāni khomha samaṇā, idāni khomha brāhmaṇā, idāni khomha arahanto’ti.
mn89:17.19.eng: But now we really are ascetics, brahmins, and perfected ones!’

mn89:17.20.pli: Ayampi kho me, bhante, bhagavati dhammanvayo hoti:
mn89:17.20.eng: So I infer this about the Buddha from the teaching:

mn89:17.21.pli: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.
mn89:17.21.eng: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’

mn89:18.1.pli: Puna caparāhaṃ, bhante, ime isidattapurāṇā thapatayo mamabhattā mamayānā, ahaṃ nesaṃ jīvikāya dātā, yasassa āhattā;
mn89:18.1.eng: Furthermore, these chamberlains Isidatta and Purāṇa share my meals and my carriages. I give them a livelihood and bring them renown.

mn89:18.2.pli: atha ca pana no tathā mayi nipaccakāraṃ karonti yathā bhagavati.
mn89:18.2.eng: And yet they don’t show me the same level of devotion that they show to the Buddha.

mn89:18.3.pli: Bhūtapubbāhaṃ, bhante, senaṃ abbhuyyāto samāno ime ca isidattapurāṇā thapatayo vīmaṃsamāno aññatarasmiṃ sambādhe āvasathe vāsaṃ upagacchiṃ.
mn89:18.3.eng: Once it so happened that while I was leading a military campaign and testing Isidatta and Purāṇa I took up residence in a cramped house.

mn89:18.4.pli: Atha kho, bhante, ime isidattapurāṇā thapatayo bahudeva rattiṃ dhammiyā kathāya vītināmetvā, yato ahosi bhagavā tato sīsaṃ katvā maṃ pādato karitvā nipajjiṃsu.
mn89:18.4.eng: They spent much of the night discussing the teaching, then they lay down with their heads towards where the Buddha was and their feet towards me.

mn89:18.7.pli: Ime isidattapurāṇā thapatayo mamabhattā mamayānā, ahaṃ nesaṃ jīvikāya dātā, yasassa āhattā;
mn89:18.7.eng: These chamberlains Isidatta and Purāṇa share my meals and my carriages. I give them a livelihood and bring them renown.

mn89:18.8.pli: atha ca pana no tathā mayi nipaccakāraṃ karonti yathā bhagavati.
mn89:18.8.eng: And yet they don’t show me the same level of devotion that they show to the Buddha.

mn89:18.9.pli: Addhā ime āyasmanto tassa bhagavato sāsane uḷāraṃ pubbenāparaṃ visesaṃ jānantī’ti.
mn89:18.9.eng: Clearly these venerables have realized a higher distinction in the Buddha’s instructions than they had before.’
mn89:18.9.comm: They were at least stream-enterers (SN 55.6:18.1, AN 6.120–139:1.12), and died as once-returners (AN 6.44:2.3, AN 10.75:2.2). | The king refers to his subordinates with āyasmā, normally reserved for addressing mendicants. When used by lay people of other lay people it indicates deep respect, often, as here, in reference to noble individuals on the path (MN 68:18.5, SN 55.54:2.2), or else used by a criminal beseeching the mercy of the crowd (AN 4.244:2.2).

mn89:18.10.pli: Ayampi kho me, bhante, bhagavati dhammanvayo hoti:
mn89:18.10.eng: So I infer this about the Buddha from the teaching:

mn89:18.11.pli: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.
mn89:18.11.eng: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’

mn89:19.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhante, bhagavāpi khattiyo, ahampi khattiyo;
mn89:19.1.eng: Furthermore, the Buddha is an aristocrat, and so am I.

mn89:19.2.eng: The Buddha is Kosalan, and so am I.
mn89:19.2.comm: The Sakyans were vassals of Kosala (Snp 3.1:18.4).

mn89:19.3.eng: The Buddha is eighty years old, and so am I.
mn89:19.3.comm: This sets these events in the last year of the Buddha’s life.

mn89:19.4.pli: Yampi, bhante, bhagavāpi khattiyo ahampi khattiyo, bhagavāpi kosalo ahampi kosalo, bhagavāpi āsītiko ahampi āsītiko;

mn89:19.5.pli: imināvārahāmevāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavati paramanipaccakāraṃ kātuṃ, mittūpahāraṃ upadaṃsetuṃ.
mn89:19.5.eng: it’s proper for me to act with such utmost deference for the Buddha and demonstrate such friendship.

mn89:20.1.pli: Handa ca dāni mayaṃ, bhante, gacchāma;
mn89:20.1.eng: Well, now, sir, I must go.

mn89:20.2.eng: I have many duties, and much to do.”

mn89:20.3.eng: “Please, great king, go at your convenience.”

mn89:20.4.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
mn89:20.4.eng: Then King Pasenadi got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
mn89:20.4.comm: While the sutta and its parallels do not hint at anything other than a respectful visit to the Buddha, there is a tradition that this event led to Pasenadi’s downfall. Apparently, Dīgha Kārāyana blamed Pasenadi for the death of his uncle, Pasenadi’s former general Bandhula. Seeking revenge, he took the royal insignia and crowned Pasanadi’s dubious son Viḍūḍabha (MN 90:6.1) in his stead. Abandoned and alone, Pasenadi sought shelter in Rājagaha with his nephew Ajātasattu, but arrived too late and died while spending the night outside the walls. The details are improbable—why flee his friends the Sakyans for the untrustworthy Ajātasattu, 500 kms distant? And why would a city watch bar a king in need? Nonetheless, the outline of this story is found widely, not just in the Pali commentary (see Ja 465, T 1451 at T xxiv 238c1, T 211 at T iv 583a16, D (6) ’dul ba, tha 86a7).

mn89:21.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā acirapakkantassa rañño pasenadissa kosalassa bhikkhū āmantesi:
mn89:21.1.eng: Soon after the king had left, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

mn89:21.2.pli: “eso, bhikkhave, rājā pasenadi kosalo dhammacetiyāni bhāsitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkanto.
mn89:21.2.eng: “Mendicants, before he got up and left, King Pasenadi spoke shrines to the teaching.

mn89:21.3.eng: Learn these shrines to the teaching!

mn89:21.4.eng: Memorize these shrines to the teaching!

mn89:21.5.eng: Remember these shrines to the teaching!

mn89:21.6.eng: These shrines to the teaching are beneficial and relate to the fundamentals of the spiritual life.”

mn89:21.7.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn89:21.8.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn89:21.8.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
